factoid: Old Bolkónski had always had a poor opinion of Prince Vasíli's character.
Old Bolkónski had a poor opinion of Prince Vasíli's character more so recently.
Prince Vasíli had risen to a high position and honors during the reigns of Paul and Alexander.
Old Bolkónski saw which way the wind was blowing.
Old Bolkónski's low opinion changed into a feeling of contemptuous ill will.
Old Bolkónski snorted whenever he mentioned Prince Vasíli.
Prince Bolkónski was discontented on the day of Prince Vasíli's arrival.
Prince Bolkónski was out of temper on the day of Prince Vasíli's arrival.
Old Bolkónski was in a bad temper in the morning.
Tíkhon advised the architect not to go to Prince Vasíli with his report in the morning.
Prince Vasíli wore a velvet coat with a sable collar and a cap.
The day before, it had snowed.
The path to the hothouse had been swept.
The marks of the broom were still visible in the snow.
A shovel was left sticking in one of the soft snowbanks that bordered both sides of the path.
Prince Vasíli walked through the conservatories.
Prince Vasíli walked through the serfs’ quarters.
Prince Vasíli walked through the outbuildings.
Prince Vasíli was frowning and silent while walking.
Prince Vasíli asked his overseer if a sleigh could pass.
The overseer was a venerable man resembling Prince Vasíli in manners and looks.
The overseer accompanied Prince Vasíli back to the house.
The overseer said that the snow was deep.
The overseer said that he was having the avenue swept.
The overseer thought that the storm had blown over.
The overseer said that it would have been hard to drive up.
The overseer said that he had heard that a minister was coming to visit Prince Vasíli.
Prince Vasíli turned around to the overseer and fixed his eyes on him.
Prince Vasíli was frowning.
Prince Vasíli asked what minister and who gave orders.
Prince Vasíli said that the road was not swept for the princess but for a minister.
Prince Vasíli said that for him there were no ministers.
The overseer said "Your honor, I thought…".
Prince Vasíli shouted "You thought!".
Prince Vasíli shouted "Rascals! Blackguards!".
Prince Vasíli said "I’ll teach you to think!".
Prince Vasíli lifted his stick and swung it.
Prince Vasíli would have hit the overseer Alpátych.
Alpátych instinctively avoided the blow.
Alpátych was frightened by his own temerity in avoiding the stroke.
Alpátych came up to Prince Vasíli.
Alpátych bowed his bald head before Prince Vasíli.
Prince Vasíli continued to shout "Blackguards!… Throw the snow back on the road!".
Prince Vasíli did not lift his stick again.
Prince Vasíli hurried into the house.
Princess Mary and Mademoiselle Bourienne stood awaiting Prince Vasíli.
Princess Mary was pale, frightened, and had downcast eyes.
Mademoiselle Bourienne had a radiant face.
Mademoiselle Bourienne said "I know nothing, I am the same as usual."
Princess Mary thought that if she seemed not to notice, Prince Vasíli would think that she did not sympathize with him.
Princess Mary thought that if she seemed sad and out of spirits, Prince Vasíli would say that she was in the dumps.
Princess Mary found it hardest to bear that she ought to behave like Mademoiselle Bourienne on such occasions.
Princess Mary could not behave like Mademoiselle Bourienne.
Prince Vasíli looked at Princess Mary’s frightened face.
Prince Vasíli snorted.
Prince Vasíli muttered "Fool… or dummy!".
Prince Vasíli thought that the other one was not here.
Prince Vasíli thought that the other one was telling tales.
Prince Vasíli referred to the little princess who was not in the dining room.
Prince Vasíli asked "Where is the princess?".
Prince Vasíli asked "Hiding?".
Mademoiselle Bourienne answered that the little princess is not very well.
Mademoiselle Bourienne answered that the little princess would not come down.
Mademoiselle Bourienne answered that it is natural in the little princess’s state.
Prince Vasíli muttered "Hm! Hm!".
Prince Vasíli sat down.
